name: gemini
answer: The image shows an aurora, also known as the northern lights or southern lights, which is a natural light display in the Earth's sky, predominantly seen in high-latitude regions.  Auroras are produced when the magnetosphere is sufficiently disturbed by the solar wind. These disturbances are caused by variations in the solar wind that produces a solar storm which, in turn, accelerates the particles away from the Sun and towards the Earth. These particles enter the atmosphere from above the Earth's magnetic poles and collide with gas particles, causing the ionization or excitation of these particles. The ionized particles return to their ground state, releasing energy in the form of photons. This process gives rise to the emission of light of various colors and shapes in the sky, creating the effect of an aurora. The color produced is dependent on the type of atmospheric gas particles that are excited. The most common auroral color, a pale green or yellow-green, is produced by oxygen atoms excited at an altitude of around 100 km (62 mi). A red aurora is produced by oxygen atoms at higher altitudes, around 200–400 km (120–250 mi). A purple aurora is caused by nitrogen molecules excited at an altitude of around 100 km (62 mi).
